description:
Drosophila erecta is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the Drosophila genus. It is commonly known as the Erecta fruit fly or the Savanna fruit fly. Drosophila erecta is a small insect, measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length, with a body that is typically yellowish-brown in color.

This species is native to parts of sub-Saharan Africa, where it can be found in various habitats, including savannas, forests, and grasslands. Drosophila erecta is known for its unique courtship behavior, where the male flies perform a series of complex dances and displays to attract the female.

Genetically, Drosophila erecta is closely related to other members of the Drosophila genus, and it has been used extensively in scientific research, particularly in the field of evolutionary biology and genetics. The species has a relatively short life cycle, with the entire life cycle, from egg to adult, taking approximately 2-3 weeks under optimal conditions.

Overall, Drosophila erecta is an important model organism in the study of various biological processes, including development, behavior, and the evolution of species.
